genetic map based on co-dominant markers (SSRs, Indels
and SNPs) with known ﬂanking sequences was established for
Important success has been accomplished in the ﬁeld of structural
genomics in the last 10 years: reference genomes assembled in
pseudomolecules were released for sweet orange (
the interspeciﬁc admixture of modern varieties (
). QTLs for resistances to diseases and pests (e.g., CTV,
) have been developed, and also for morphological and/or
quality traits [fruit acidity, polyembryony, and apomixes; (
potential of genome wide selection in citrus for fruit acid
and sugar contents. However, the learning and applications
populations were limited to one parental combination. Working
with composite populations associating traditional germplasms
developed GS models for quality traits based on wider
Unfortunately, QTL and bulk segregant analyses for the
identiﬁcation of markers linked with tolerance to abiotic stresses
for olive breeding and therefore for genetic and genomic studies.
Genetic maps and QTL analysis are generally developed from
sexual crosses between two heterozygous varieties. The Gene
tree breeding is a promising tool to develop further GWAS
is considered a diploid species with
) proposed that the species had originated
from interspeciﬁc crosses, probably by parentals whose haploid
several species of the Oleaceae family. The nuclear DNA content
cultivars estimated by ﬂow cytometry ranged
between 1.45 and 1.53 Gb/haploid genome and the genome size
of wild olive was estimated 1.59 Gb/haploid genome (
). Many molecular studies in olive, including the
most recent, are based on dominant markers such as Random
Length Polymorphism(AFLP), or Inter Simple Sequence Repeats
(ISSR) despite much more useful co-dominant markers have
been developed during the recent years (see
for review). First olive SSR markers were published
have been developed from EST data (
). Until now, there is no SNP microarray for
high-throughput genotyping but GBS has been successfully
developed rendering saturated maps with more than 4,000 SNP
added new markers and particularly SSRs
) producing the most saturated olive map generated
with traditional molecular markers. Several whole genome
sequencing projects engaged during the last years: one by an
Italian consortium within the framework of the OLEA project
project that sequenced a 1,000-years old tree of the Spanish
genome of 1.31 Gb, representing 95% of the estimated genome
length. Nevertheless, few QTL analyses have been published so
an association study with olive oil quality criteria. A genetic
association study was performed with SSRs markers to develop
reported the ﬁrst GWAS study for yield-related traits.
Polyploidy has been identiﬁed as a major force driving plant
evolution in order to better adapt to environmental constraints
investigations during the last decade showed that inducing
polyploidization in diploid genomes improves stress tolerance
investigation on the role of polyploidization in stress tolerance
is hampered in part by the phylogenomic history of the given
plant species, the biology and the particular genetic structure
). To this respect, citrus have the
advantage that, although most cultivated genotypes are diploid,
apomictic seeds produced in several citrus species exhibit the
boosted the selection and investigation of polyploids in citrus as
In citrus, polyploidy is often associated to a wide range
of morphological and physiological changes that are often
